subNodes.conversationText: "Sudder! Sudder! Where are you?" A young woman -- little more than a girl, really -- stood on the steps of the little cabin, calling out. When she saw <FirstName>, she stopped and stared, then screamed: "SUUDDER!"
Sudder himself, a middle-aged man in hunting leathers with a quiver on his back, stepped out of the woods. He was red and out of breath. "Quiet, girl! What is it? What are you screaming about?"
Then he saw the young witch. "Who are you? A visitor? Where'd you come from, the inn? Not a good time to be wandering."
A woman who had been struggling to hang a deer carcass on a tree limb stopped her work. She stared at <FirstName>.
"Are you? Well, I don't want any trouble. I'm just a poor hunter trying to make it out here with my family. I know enough to respect your kind."
"Don't keep <him/her> standing there in this heat, Sudder. Let's all go inside. It's cooler, and we've got dandelion wine."

"Aren't you gonna introduce us, Sudder?"

The young woman had been gazing at <FirstName> the whole time as if trying to make sense of what she was seeing.
"The witch doesn't care about two silly girls."

"Fine, but quit your wheedling."

"These are my wives. This one's name is Niana, but I call her Nunny. The one with the deer is Jalbetha."

<FirstName> noticed that both women were pregnant.
"I've got an idea!" she said. "Why don't we go on inside? It's a little cooler, and I can pour you some dandelion wine and you two can talk about whatever you want."
Jalbetha, who had been staring silently at <FirstName> the whole time, now stared at her co-wife.
"I'm a witch. As it happens, I'm looking for a hunter."
"Well, I'm a hunter, but I don't think it's me you're looking for."
"I'm just surviving out here with my family. I don't make trouble. I know enough to respect your kind."
"Don't keep <him/her> standing there in this heat, Sudder. Let's all go inside. It's cooler, and we've got dandelion wine."
Jalbetha, who had been staring silently at <FirstName> the whole time, now stared at her co-wife.
The old hunter gave Nunny a sharp look.
"All right. All right," Sudder said slowly. He was too smart to offend a witch. "What do you say, witch? Do you want to step inside?"
"Yes. I have things to ask you."

Sudder and Nunny went in with <FirstName>, but Jalbetha stayed outside to continue her work. Pharaoh came in too. The bird's presence delighted Nunny.

They entered a messy, unwholesome-smelling kitchen. A flimsy screen separated it from the shack's only other room, where <FirstName> could see the foot of a single big bed. Sudder sat down at the table while Nunny got out the dandelion wine.
"You don't look old to me, so you must not be Eldest Lady."
"My! That's an interesting name, isn't it, Sudder?"
"Well, <FirstName>, do you always carry a gourd around with you?"
"Yes. A harmless bit of witchcraft. It brings good luck."
"Hear that, Sudder? That's what I've been missing. I need to get me a gourd." She put cups on the table and started pouring the dandelion wine.
"You're lucker than you've any right to be, girl," said Sudder, scowling.

Tthere was a commotion outside -- the sound of something breaking -- a thud -- and Jalbetha yelling. Sudder jumped up. Nunny, startled, knocked over <FirstName>'s cup. Everyone ran out to see what was going on.
"No. It usually walks around on its own."
"Hahaha! You're funny. I like you. Wasn't that funny, Sudder?" She put cups on the table and started pouring the dandelion wine.
"Sure was," said Sudder without a smile.

Tthere was a commotion outside -- the sound of something breaking -- a thud -- and Jalbetha yelling. Sudder jumped up. Nunny, startled, knocked over <FirstName>'s cup. Everyone ran out to see what was going on.
ignored the question. "I'm here because I have questions for you."

Then they heard a commotion outside -- something breaking, a thud, Jalbetha yelling.

Sudder jumped up. Nunny, startled, knocked over <FirstName>'s cup. Everyone ran out to see what was going on.
It was nothing. The deer carcass had been too heavy for the tree. The limb had broken, and the deer had fallen down. Jalbetha was uninjured.
"Damn it Jalbetha, I knew you wouldn't do those ropes right. Go inside. I'll fix this. Can't have the dirt getting all over it."
"I could help," volunteered the young witch.
<FirstName> went back inside with Sudder's two wives.
<FirstName> went back inside with Sudder's two wives.

As soon as the door was closed, Nunny dropped to the ground in front of <FirstName>.

"Help us," she said in a panicked whisper. "Help us. We don't want to be here anymore."
"Time to leave. Time to kill him. To kill Sudder."
"Kill Sudder? What is this talk? Don't listen to her, stranger! I don't know what's gotten into her. Nunny, Nunny! Sudder loves you, do you hear? He loves us."
"No he don't. Didn't he kill my dad?"
"Killed your dad? No! You don't even know who your dad is. What's gotten into you? What's gotten into you?"

Knott, who had been resting on the table in gourd form, moved. The two young women didn't notice.

Then <FirstName> felt it: there was magic in the air as hot and oppressive as the August heat.
"My! That's an interesting name, isn't it, Sudder?"
"Thought so. So who are you then?"
"You're a man, and you're not very old. So you must not be Eldest Lady."
"Very well. But I can't stay long.

Sudder and Nunny went in with <FirstName>, but Jalbetha stayed outside to continue her work. Pharaoh came in too. The bird's presence delighted Nunny.

They entered a messy, unwholesome-smelling kitchen. A flimsy screen separated it from the shack's only other room, where <FirstName> could see the foot of a single big bed. Sudder sat down at the table while Nunny got out the dandelion wine.
"No. I must be on my way."
"Is that so? Well, may fortune follow you." The hunter's relief was obvious. "Maybe we'll cross paths again -- and maybe we won't."
"Hmm... On second thought, dandelion wine does sound good."

Sudder and Nunny went in with <FirstName>, but Jalbetha stayed outside to continue her work. Pharaoh came in too. The bird's presence delighted Nunny.

They entered a messy, unwholesome-smelling kitchen. A flimsy screen separated it from the shack's only other room, where <FirstName> could see the foot of a single big bed. Sudder sat down at the table while Nunny got out the dandelion wine.
He thanked her and went inside.
Nunny shook her head, gave <FirstName> a reproachful look, and obeyed.

"Aren't you gonna introduce us, Sudder?"

The young woman had been gazing at <FirstName> the whole time as if trying to make sense of what she was seeing.
